articles.headline: Short Seller Sinks Teeth Into Insurer
articles.snippet: A hedge fund manager known for shareholder activism has pursued MBIA Inc. with sheer, obsessive doggedness.
articles.abstract: A hedge fund manager known for shareholder activism has pursued MBIA Inc. with sheer, obsessive doggedness.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m going to try to give shorter answers,” said William Ackman, with an awkward smile.

articles.headline: Labor Pacts in Detroit Didn’t Ease Stocks’ Slide
articles.snippet: Despite winning labor contracts that improved their competitiveness, shares in G.M. and Ford have continued to slide.
articles.abstract: Despite winning labor contracts that improved their competitiveness, shares in G.M. and Ford have continued to slide.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Nov. 30 — Detroit auto companies have long expected a quid pro quo from Wall Street when it came to their dealings with the United Automobile Workers union.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Nigeria Turns From Harsher Side of Islamic Law
articles.snippet: An Islamic revolution in northern Nigeria appears to have come and gone — or gone in an unexpected direction.
articles.abstract: An Islamic revolution in northern Nigeria appears to have come and gone — or gone in an unexpected direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria  Just last year, the morality police roamed these streets in dusky blue uniforms and black berets, brandishing cudgels at prayer shirkers and dragging fornicators into Islamic courts to face sentences like death by public stoning.

articles.headline: Motivating the Motivator
articles.snippet: Some surveys reveal that the number of employees who are truly engaged by their work may be as low as 25 percent.
articles.abstract: Some surveys reveal that the number of employees who are truly engaged by their work may be as low as 25 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S an old joke. A visitor is being shown around the office and asks, “How many people work here?”

articles.headline: U.S. Urges Freezing Some Rates on Loans
articles.snippet: Treasury officials said they were pleased by the progress in persuading mortgage lenders to agree to a temporary rate freeze on subprime loans to avert foreclosures.
articles.abstract: Treasury officials said they were pleased by the progress in persuading mortgage lenders to agree to a temporary rate freeze on subprime loans to avert foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Treasury Department is leaning on mortgage lenders to temporarily freeze the interest rates on subprime loans for homeowners threatened with foreclosure, but the scope of any relief will depend on crucial details.

articles.headline: Wall St. Sees Silver Lining in Economy
articles.snippet: Investors appear to be taking comfort in the notion that the economy is so imperiled that it is forcing the government to mount an aggressive rescue effort.
articles.abstract: Investors appear to be taking comfort in the notion that the economy is so imperiled that it is forcing the government to mount an aggressive rescue effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wall Street rallied this week, it seemed that investors were taking comfort in the notion that the economy had become so imperiled by the crumbling housing market that it was forcing the government to finally mount an aggressive rescue effort.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Set Deal on Raising Fuel Efficiency
articles.snippet: Congressional negotiators reached a deal on legislation to require automakers to achieve 35 miles per gallon on average by 2020.
articles.abstract: Congressional negotiators reached a deal on legislation to require automakers to achieve 35 miles per gallon on average by 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — Congressional negotiators reached a deal late Friday on energy legislation that would force American automakers to improve the fuel efficiency of their cars and light trucks by 40 percent by 2020.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Both Sides in Writers’ Strike See New-Media Future at Stake
articles.snippet: Striking writers angrily rejected an elaborate package of new proposals from their employers just hours after it was presented.
articles.abstract: Striking writers angrily rejected an elaborate package of new proposals from their employers just hours after it was presented.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 — The nearly month-old strike by screenwriters has entered a new and perhaps uglier phase, revealing the conflict for what it has been all along: not so much a tiff over industry economics as a struggle for power over Hollywood’s perceived digital future.

articles.headline: Top Ranks of Women on Wall Street are Shrinking
articles.snippet: The top executive ranks at the big Wall Street firms remain largely devoid of women seen with a viable chance of becoming chief executive anytime soon.
articles.abstract: The top executive ranks at the big Wall Street firms remain largely devoid of women seen with a viable chance of becoming chief executive anytime soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1982, John J. Mack, now the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, interviewed a fresh-faced Harvard Business School graduate named Zoe Cruz for an associate position in the firm’s bond trading business.

articles.headline: Witness Names to Be Withheld From Detainee
articles.snippet: Lawyers for a Guantánamo detainee have been ordered not to tell their client — or anyone else — the identity of witnesses against him.
articles.abstract: Lawyers for a Guantánamo detainee have been ordered not to tell their client — or anyone else — the identity of witnesses against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Defense lawyers preparing for the war crimes trial of a 21-year-old Guantánamo detainee have been ordered by a military judge not to tell their client  or anyone else  the identity of witnesses against him, newly released documents show.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Sends Investors to the Children’s Table
articles.snippet: A vote by the Securities and Exchange Commission will prevent shareholders from nominating their own director candidates.
articles.abstract: A vote by the Securities and Exchange Commission will prevent shareholders from nominating their own director candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALK about a one-two punch.

articles.headline: The Long and Short of It at Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: An analysis by a Goldman economist deserves its own analysis.
articles.abstract: An analysis by a Goldman economist deserves its own analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR decades now, as a writer, economist and scold, I have been receiving letters from thoughtful readers. Many of them have warned me about the dangers of a secret government running the world, organized by the Trilateral Commission, or the Ford Foundation, or the Big Oil companies or, of course, world Jewry.

articles.headline: Meteorologists Shape Fashion Trends
articles.snippet: As volatile weather alters the sale of warm clothing, the apparel industry turns to climate science for help.
articles.abstract: As volatile weather alters the sale of warm clothing, the apparel industry turns to climate science for help.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the capricious world of fashion, where hemlines, fabrics and colors fall in and out of favor with breathtaking speed, designers and retailers have always relied on one constant — the orderly changing of the seasons.

articles.headline: Housing Crisis? Try Mobile McMansions
articles.snippet: With an uncertain economy and gas prices through the roof, sales of recreational vehicles are slipping, although the most expensive R.V.’s are still moving off the lot.
articles.abstract: With an uncertain economy and gas prices through the roof, sales of recreational vehicles are slipping, although the most expensive R.V.’s are still moving off the lot.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

articles.headline: Ending Famine, Simply by Ignoring the Experts
articles.snippet: Malawi’s agricultural turnaround has implications for fighting hunger across Africa.
articles.abstract: Malawi’s agricultural turnaround has implications for fighting hunger across Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: LILONGWE, Malawi — Malawi hovered for years at the brink of famine. After a disastrous corn harvest in 2005, almost five million of its 13 million people needed emergency food aid.

articles.headline: Nonstop Theft and Bribery Stagger Iraq
articles.snippet: There is a growing sense that Iraq has slipped to new depths of lawlessness even as security has improved.
articles.abstract: There is a growing sense that Iraq has slipped to new depths of lawlessness even as security has improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 1 — Jobless men pay $500 bribes to join the police. Families build houses illegally on government land, carwashes steal water from public pipes, and nearly everything the government buys or sells can now be found on the black market.

articles.headline: Feminist Pitch by a Democrat Named Obama
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama’s campaign argues that the best candidate for women may, in fact, be a man.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama’s campaign argues that the best candidate for women may, in fact, be a man.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 — In the intensifying battle for the votes of Democratic women, Senator Barack Obama’s campaign is trying to turn years of feminist thinking on its head and argue that the best candidate for women may, in fact, be a man.

articles.headline: U.S. Credit Crisis Adds to Gloom in Norway
articles.snippet: Norwegian towns that lost millions in bad investments fear that they will have to cut local services.
articles.abstract: Norwegian towns that lost millions in bad investments fear that they will have to cut local services.

articles.headline: Lessons From Rosie, Revisited
articles.snippet: In some ways, Judith Regan’s civil suit against the News Corporation mirrors the confrontation between Rosie O’Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA in 2002.
articles.abstract: In some ways, Judith Regan’s civil suit against the News Corporation mirrors the confrontation between Rosie O’Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA in 2002.
articles.lead_paragraph: Say what you will about Judith Regan — most people have — she knows her way around a rip-roaring read. The complaint in her $100 million civil suit against the News Corporation, with its riveting passages about corporate connivance, public malfeasance and ill-fated romance, is as much a page-turner as any of the dozens of salacious best sellers she produced at ReganBooks, her imprint at HarperCollins before she was fired at the end of last year.

articles.headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
articles.snippet: The deal would create a rival to Electronic Arts as the  largest independent video game publisher.
articles.abstract: The deal would create a rival to Electronic Arts as the  largest independent video game publisher.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 — Vivendi said Sunday that it planned to acquire a controlling stake in Activision in a deal that creates a rival to Electronic Arts as the world’s largest independent video game publisher.

articles.headline: Venezuela Hands Narrow Defeat to Chávez Plan
articles.snippet: The results of a referendum that would have given new powers to President Hugo Chávez were a stunning development in a country where he controls nearly all the levers of power.
articles.abstract: The results of a referendum that would have given new powers to President Hugo Chávez were a stunning development in a country where he controls nearly all the levers of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Monday, Dec. 3 — Voters in this country narrowly defeated a proposed overhaul to the constitution in a contentious referendum over granting President Hugo Chávez sweeping new powers, the Election Commission announced early Monday.

articles.headline: Spam’s End? Maybe, if Time Allows
articles.snippet: Twenty-five years ago Steven T. Kirsch built a better mouse. Now he believes he has found a way to create a better trap for spam.
articles.abstract: Twenty-five years ago Steven T. Kirsch built a better mouse. Now he believes he has found a way to create a better trap for spam.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Twenty-five years ago Steven T. Kirsch built a better mouse. Now he believes he has found a way to create a better trap  for spam, not mice  if he has enough time to finish his project.

articles.headline: New Orleans Hurt by Acute Rental Shortage
articles.snippet: New Orleans is suffering from an acute shortage of housing that has nearly doubled the cost of rental units.
articles.abstract: New Orleans is suffering from an acute shortage of housing that has nearly doubled the cost of rental units.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 — Inside trailer No. 27 here at the A. L. Davis Playground, where the government set up a camp last year for displaced residents of Hurricane Katrina, Tracy Bernard’s meager possessions are all packed up, even though she has nowhere to go.

articles.headline: OPEC’s Tough Call: Raise or Hold Oil Supply
articles.snippet: After a year of dizzying gains for energy markets, a rapid fall in oil prices lately is posing a dilemma for OPEC, the oil-producing cartel.
articles.abstract: After a year of dizzying gains for energy markets, a rapid fall in oil prices lately is posing a dilemma for OPEC, the oil-producing cartel.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of dizzying gains for energy markets, a rapid fall in oil prices lately is posing a dilemma for OPEC, the oil-producing cartel.

articles.headline: Lonely No More, Huckabee Faces Hurdles
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee has emerged as a force in the Republican field, but a surge now may not translate to success later.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee has emerged as a force in the Republican field, but a surge now may not translate to success later.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Dec. 2 — Mike Huckabee spent the weekend in New Hampshire, where he saw something he had rarely seen in his two years as a Republican candidate for president: People. Lots of them. Living rooms and halls packed with voters, campaign aides, reporters and jostling television crews.

articles.headline: NBC to Pay Outsiders for Blocks of Programs
articles.snippet: NBC has made an ambitious deal, apparently the first of its kind, to buy a block of prime-time programming from outside producers.
articles.abstract: NBC has made an ambitious deal, apparently the first of its kind, to buy a block of prime-time programming from outside producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC has made an ambitious deal, apparently the first of its kind, to buy a two-hour — or perhaps even three-hour — block of prime-time programming from outside producers, including Thom Beers, the creator of adventure documentary series like “Deadliest Catch” and “Ice Road Truckers.”

articles.headline: Nevada Learns to Cash In on Sales of Federal Land
articles.snippet: Nevada is reaping the rewards from the sale of almost $3 billion of federal lands near Las Vegas.
articles.abstract: Nevada is reaping the rewards from the sale of almost $3 billion of federal lands near Las Vegas.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When it opens in 2009, the Clark County Shooting Park will be something to behold, through a scope or otherwise: hundreds of acres devoted to all things gun and bow, complete with a rifle range, a skeet center and an R.V. “host area.”
articles.byline: By JESSE McKINLEY  and GRIFFIN PALMER

articles.headline: Party’s Triumph Raises Question of Putin’s Plans
articles.snippet: As President Putin has been accumulating popularity, he has been stirring deep uncertainty about his intentions, creating a new era of instability for Russia.
articles.abstract: As President Putin has been accumulating popularity, he has been stirring deep uncertainty about his intentions, creating a new era of instability for Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 —With President Vladimir V. Putin’s opponents persistently hobbled by the Kremlin, his party swept Sunday to the kind of landslide long predicted for the parliamentary elections. Yet the results, while a triumph for Mr. Putin, also usher in a new era of political instability for Russia.
